p: Liudong Xing (SM'07) received her M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Virginia (U.Va.) in 2000, and 2002, respectively. She is now an Associate Professor with the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth. Dr. Xing served as a program co-chair for IEEE DASC 2006 & UC-Sec 2009, a program vice chair for ICESS 2007 & ICPADS 2008, and an associate guest editor for the Journal of Computer Science on a special issue of “Reliability and Autonomic Management” in 2006. She is the Editor for Short Communications in the International Journal of Performability Engineering. Dr. Xing is the recipient of the IEEE Region 1 Technological Innovation (Academic) Award in 2007. Her current research interests include dependable computing and networking, reliability engineering, fault-intrusion tolerant computing, and wireless sensor networks. She is a senior member of IEEE, and a member of Eta Kappa Nu.

p: Akhilesh Shrestha (S'03) was awarded the M.S. degree in Computer Engineering from the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth in 2005. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth. His current research interests include fault tolerant and dependable computing, wireless sensor networks, and database systems. He has been a student member of IEEE since 2003.

p: Leila Meshkat is a Senior Engineer at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), and a part time faculty member at the USC School of Engineering. Prior to joining JPL, she was a Research Associate at the USC Information Sciences Institute. She holds a Ph.D. in Systems Engineering from the University of Virginia, an M.S. in Operations Research from George Washington University, and a B.S. in Applied Mathematics. Her current interests include Model Based Engineering Design, Probabilistic Risk Assessment, Software Architecture Development, and the infusion of Risk Based Decision Making techniques in the JPL processes and practices.

p: Wendai Wang is a Senior Member of Technical Staff at the Applied Materials. He received his B.S. and M.S. from Shanghai Jiaotong University, and his Ph.D. from the University of Arizona. He has about 20-year industry and research experience in Reliability and Maintainability Engineering. He is the author of over 30 publications and invention disclosures, and has successfully led many innovative “design-for-reliability (DFR)” projects. His work and research area includes DFR methodology and process, system reliability and availability modeling and analysis, reliability prediction, reliability testing, reliability growth, mechanical reliability, electronics reliability, physics of failure, and reliability training.

details.abstract: This paper considers the problem of evaluating the reliability of hierarchical systems subject to common-cause failures (CCF); and dynamic failure behavior such as spares, functional dependence, priority dependence, and dependence caused by multi-phased operations. We present a separable solution that has low computational complexity, and which is easy to integrate into existing analytical methods. The resulting approach is applicable to Markov analyses, and combinatorial models for the modular analysis of the system reliability. We illustrate the approach, and the advantages of the proposed approach, through the detailed analyses of two examples of dynamic hierarchical systems subject to CCF.

context.text: HS, especially those designed with redundancy techniques [2], can be subject to common cause failures (CCF), where multiple components fail simultaneously due to a shared root cause or common cause (CC).
Considerable research works have incorporated CCF into the reliability modeling of computer-based systems [2]–[10].
Existing methods can be broadly classified into two categories: explicit methods [4]–[6], and implicit methods [2], [3].

For example, the explicit methods presented in [4]–[6] are subject to combinatorial explosion as the redundancy level of the system, and the number of components affected by CCF, increase; the implicit method presented in [2] limits analysis to components affected by at most one CC, and has CC that can only affect \$s\$-identical components.

context.text: Considerable research works have incorporated CCF into the reliability modeling of computer-based systems [2]–[10].
Most of these methods suffer from one or more limitations, as summarized in [10].

In an effort to address these limitations, we proposed an efficient decomposition and aggregation (EDA) approach for the reliability analysis of systems subject to general CCF in our previous work [10].
As mentioned in Section I, the EDA approach proposed in [10] is only applicable to static HS where the failure criteria of the system depend only on the combinations of component failure events.
According to [10], we define a common-cause event (CCE) space over a set of \$2^{m}\$ collectively exhaustive, mutually exclusive CCE.
For static HS, the set \$S_{CCE_{i}}\$ is simply the union of CCG whose corresponding elementary CC occur [10].

After CCF are out of the picture, due to the layered peculiarity of HS, a modular and hierarchical decomposition method (see, e.g., [10], [14], [19], [20]) can be used to “peel” back the layers of an HS.
Note that the CCF gate [10] is modeled after the FDEP gate for facilitating the representation of CCF in the DFT.

To solve the reduced problems of the HECS, we apply the modular, hierarchical decomposition method to resolve the system DFT into modules, and then resolve each successive module layer into components [10], [19].
Note that because the occurrence of \$CC_{3}\$ is dependent on the occurrence of \$CC_{1}\$, \$\Pr(CCE_{i})\$ has been calculated in a different way from the one used in Example I [10].

DIFtree (Dynamic Innovative Fault trees) effectively combines the best static fault tree solution technique (binary decision diagrams) with Markov solution techniques for dynamic fault trees. These approaches either assume that every phase is static, and thus can be solved with combinatorial methods, or assume that every phase must be modeled via Markov methods.
